title: Spec-ing a typeface without the typeface.
content:
I'm helping a client create a new identity; a simple wordmark/logotype. I'm interested in purchasing a new font (most likely a didone) but it is obviously not on my bill if I do.

So I've run into a problem. I know that very often designers recommend fonts and I've often wondered how do they sell it to the clients or <cite>themselves</cite> if they can't see it in front of them. I realize some of you may not need to see it to know if it will work, but I am extremely visual—I need to see it in front of me.

I know that there's a testdrive on most typographer's websites, but I'm running into issues where I want to do different typefaces or different weights. Any suggestions?

(I know that I can screenshot, but that's incredibly inefficient.)
author: James Deux

comments.content:
<cite> > I’ve often wondered how do they sell it to the clients or themselves if they can’t see it in front of them.</cite>

In the old days, we'd do it by developing tight sketches.
Haha well I could always pull out a pad of tracing paper. That wouldn't be the worst thing!

<cite>(I know that I can screenshot, but that’s incredibly inefficient.)</cite>

Perhaps, it depends on the screen shot. But no matter what it looks like it is better than nothing.

A tight sketch can be a beautiful thing!
If this is a big client and might result in a big sale you might be able to work something out with the designer.

<cite> > A tight sketch can be a beautiful thing!</cite>

And sometimes the final setting was a disappointment in comparison!

Yes, sort of how people look more attractive from a distance.
